content: The Act titled "Tax Relief Improvement Act of 2001" includes a provision for a reduced capital gains rate for individuals. The Tax Relief Improvement Act of 2001 includes an amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, which sets a maximum capital gains rate for taxpayers with a net capital gain. The tax imposed for the taxable year is limited to a certain percentage of the taxpayer's net capital gain or taxable income. Conforming amendments are made to various sections of the Code, including the repeal of section 1202 relating to the 50-percent exclusion for gain from certain small business stock. Amendments are made to various sections of the Code, including changes to the deductibility of losses and inclusion of gains from sales or exchanges of capital assets for taxpayers other than corporations. Amendments to various sections of the Code include changes to tax rates and redesignation of subsections. The Merchant Marine Act of 1936 is amended to change the tax rate from 28 percent to 15 percent. The effective dates for these amendments are for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2001, with a specific withholding amendment applying to amounts paid after the same date. SEC. 3. REPEAL OF SUNSETS OF ECONOMIC GROWTH AND TAX RELIEF RECONCILIATION ACT OF 2001. Repeal of Title IX of the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001, deduction for higher education expenses made permanent, nonrefundable credit for certain individuals for elective deferrals and IRA contributions made permanent, and increase in alternative minimum tax exemption made permanent. The exemption amounts for taxpayers other than corporations under section 55(d)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code are amended to $49,000 and $35,750. These amendments are effective as if included in the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001.
